title-group.article-title: Distinct functional potential of bacterial extracellular vesicles across biogeographic provinces of the South Pacific Ocean

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Functional and Evolutionary Ecology, Bio-Oceanography and Marine Biology Unit, https://ror.org/03prydq77University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria

5Department of Biological Sciences, https://ror.org/01srpnj69Wellesley College, Wellesley, USA

license.license-p: This work is licensed under a CC BY 4.0 International license.

abstract.p: Bacterial extracellular vesicles (BEVs) are spherical membrane-bound structures released by bacterial cells that can carry various biological compounds. Experimental investigation of BEVs in marine bacteria, largely limited to laboratory model systems, have suggested putative roles in bacterial ecophysiology. Yet the functions of BEVs in their ecological context has never been explored directly in the ocean. Here we report the results a large-scale oceanographic survey of marine BEVs in surface waters, conducted over more than 5,000 nautical miles in the South Pacific, linking their protein cargoes to the bacterial communities producing them. The presence of marine BEVs was consistently observed across a range of biogeochemical conditions, with an overall abundance comparable to that of bacterial cells (ca. 108 BEVs L-1). The protein cargoes of marine BEVs differed significantly between environmental conditions, being enriched in carbohydrate transporters and hydrolytic enzymes under phytoplankton bloom conditions, and enriched in iron uptake-related proteins in nutrient-limited waters, suggesting key extracellular functions they could perform in marine bacterial communities. Our observations highlight the ubiquity of marine BEVs and their potential functions across oceanic scales, with implications for our general understanding of key processes in marine microbial ecology.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Bacterial extracellular vesicles (BEVs) are spherical membranous structures typically ranging between 20 and 250 nm in diameter that can carry various biological cargoes (e.g., nucleic acids and proteins) over long distances in a protected and locally concentrated manner 1. Since their discovery in human-associated Escherichia coli in the 1960s 2, most research on BEVs has focused on pathogens and other host-associated bacteria 3. Although it remains unclear to what extent the release of BEVs is an active cellular process or simply a by-product of cell growth or death (i.e., lysis), a variety of BEV functions have been described to date. One of the best-documented functions of BEVs is the intercellular transfer of DNA molecules 4,5, which can facilitate the exchange of antibiotic resistance genes between different bacterial lineages 6, as well as the transfer of entire plasmids 7,8, recently termed ’vesiduction’ 9. In addition to DNA transfer, BEVs can also play a role in bacterial quorum sensing 10,11, biofilm formation 12, and contribute to microbial "warfare", where they deliver compounds that kill competing bacteria 13,14.

Because BEVs contain fragments of the releasing bacterial cell, as well as cell membrane-derived enzymes, receptors and transporters, it has been proposed that BEVs may have a variety of functions in the exocellular milieu 15,16 in addition to intercellular interactions, which may be particularly relevant for bacteria living in aqueous environments 3,17. The ocean - the largest aquatic ecosystem on Earth where bacteria are among the most abundant organisms 18 - is a highly dynamic environment both physically and biochemically. The surface waters of the ocean are characterised by a depletion of bioavailable nutrients required for life in some areas (e.g., oceanic gyres) 19 and a high availability in others (e.g., coastal upwelling regions) 20,21. To survive in such dynamic ecosystems, marine bacteria have developed a wide range of ecophysiological capabilities 22–24, and implement highly diverse nutrient and energy utilisation strategies 25–27. In the interaction between marine bacteria and their nutrient depleted environment, high cellular surface area to volume ratios provide optimal conditions for nutrient uptake 28,29. In this sense, marine BEVs can be conceptualised as an expansion of the cell surface 1 that diffuses through seawater and randomly encounters biotic and abiotic components. Existing laboratory-based observations of several isolates of globally abundant marine bacteria 30–35 suggest that BEVs may mediate specific extracellular functions in the ecophysiology of marine bacteria, such as binding specific elements (e.g., iron or phosphate) and delivering them in concentrated form to bacterial cells. However, despite the apparent ubiquity of BEVs in the marine environment 36,37 and their potential ability to impact bacterial functions, how the contents and functional potential of these nanoparticles might vary across broad oceanographic contexts is unknown.

In this study we determined the abundance and protein cargo diversity of BEVs across the surface waters of the South Pacific Ocean. By combining molecular characterisation of marine BEVs with their local microbial and biogeochemical context, we show that BEV contents vary among ocean regions and may contribute to acquisition of limiting nutrients by the local microbial community. Our observations across a large oceanic basin reinforce the hypothesis that important extracellular bacterial functions may be mediated by BEVs in the global ocean.

sec.title: Distinct biogeochemical conditions across the South Pacific Ocean
sec.p: To investigate the potential ecophysiological functions of BEVs in marine bacterial communities we sampled across diverse environmental conditions, varying in nutrient limitations and phytoplankton bloom conditions. We collected surface water (5-6 m depth) at 20 stations along a transect that spanned the South Pacific Ocean (Fig. 1A; Table S1). Detailed physicochemical characterization across this transect 38, showed that the field sampling was carried out across four oceanic provinces. Briefly, the easternmost region was the Chilean coastal upwelling zone (UP), characterised by elevated nitrate and phosphate concentrations, while depleted in dissolved iron. In this area there were elevated chlorophyll-a concentrations (ca. 3 mg m-3; Fig. S1), with the phytoplankton community mostly composed of diatoms (Fig. 1B). The transition zone between the upwelling and the subtropical gyre (TRAN) was characterised by elevated concentrations of phosphate and dissolved iron, but depleted in nitrate. This area also had relatively high chlorophyll-a concentrations (0.04-0.26 mg m-3), with mixed phytoplankton communities. The centre of the subtropical gyre (GYRE) was characterised by very low nitrate concentrations and a declining spatial gradient from east to west of phosphate concentrations, with very low chlorophyll-a concentrations (< 0.03 mg m-3). The westernmost region (WEST) was defined as the area of the subtropical gyre with the lowest phosphate concentrations (< 10 nM) and higher (compared to GYRE) chlorophyll-a concentrations (0.03-0.14 mg m-3) of predominantly cyanobacterial origins.

We found that bacterial abundance (analysed using flow cytometry) varied between the biogeochemical provinces, and the taxonomic composition of the bacterial communities (based on metagenomic characterisation) also differed significantly between them (Fig. 2; PERMANOVA test; F3,14=21.16, R2=0.82, p=0.001). To investigate the physiological and metabolic processes expressed within the bacterial communities, we characterised the proteome of the bacterial cells, identifying between 4504-6532 cellular proteins at each station (Table S1). The composition of bacterial cellular proteins was significantly different between the four regions (Fig. S2; PERMANOVA test; F3,16=2.85, R2=0.35, p=0.001). To test for the differences between the physiological and metabolic processes in bacterial communities in the different provinces, we performed differential protein abundance analyses between each pair of adjacent provinces (Table S2). The bacterial abundance was strongly elevated in the upwelling zone (9-26×108 cells L-1), with the bacterial community showing a strong heterotrophic response to the availability of organic carbon as a result of the diatom bloom. The dominant bacteria were Flavobacteriales and Cellvibrionales, which are typically active during phytoplankton blooms 39,40. In the transition zone, bacterial abundance reached 0.4-3.5×108 cells L-1, with an elevated photosynthetic activity of the cyanobacterial order Synechococcales (Prochlorococcaceae and Synechococcaceae), which was probably stimulated by a nutrient influx from a returning lateral current 38. The subtropical gyre exhibited the lowest bacterial abundances (0.2-0.9×108 cells L-1), characterised by the dominance of the oligotrophic order Pelagibacterales 41, which has previously been shown to numerically dominate the bacterial communities of the ultra-oligotrophic South Pacific subtropical gyre 42,43. In the westernmost region, bacterial abundance was significantly higher than in the subtropical gyre (0.8-1.3×108 cells L-1; Student’s t-test, p=0.002), characterised by increased activity of Prochlorococcaceae, which may have been partly facilitated by micronutrient input from a large volcanic eruption in the region two months prior to sampling 44.

sec.title: Abundance and characteristics of marine BEVs
sec.p: To investigate the abundance and diversity of marine BEVs, we sampled the extracellular size fraction corresponding to BEV-like structures (100 kDa-0.22 μm) across all stations using size fractionated filtration. To some extent, marine viruses are in the same size fraction as BEVs, and they can be a major obstacle to studying marine BEVs due to our limited ability to mechanically separate them 45–47. Therefore, we used density gradient separation to further enrich each sample for BEVs in the laboratory (see Materials and Methods). At least 50% of the purified BEVs were in the 70 to 130 nm diameter range, matching the size distributions reported for cultures of marine bacteria (Fig. S3)33,35. The abundance of BEVs was in the same order of magnitude as bacterial cells (Fig. 3). However, because the density gradient separation resulted in a reduced yield of 6-52% of all nanoparticles (Fig. S4), these are likely conservative estimates of the BEVs concentration in the seawater. We then characterised the protein cargoes of the BEV-like structures and identified 2029-3580 BEV-associated proteins at each station (Table S1). Of these proteins only 56-121 were taxonomically or functionally (e.g., capsid or tail sheath) related to viruses, suggesting a strong enrichment of BEVs in our samples. We found that 78-96% of proteins observed in the BEVs were also found in the corresponding cellular fraction at each station, but the composition of the proteins significantly varied between the two fractions (PERMANOVA test; F1,38=15.00, R2=0.28, p =0.001). This indicates that the BEVs represent a subset that differs from the full bacterial proteome.

Gram-negative marine bacteria can release BEVs through blebbing of the cellular membrane, forming particles bounded by fragments of cellular membranes and containing periplasm of the releasing bacterial cell 1,48. In addition to biases in packaging relating to subcellular localization, external factors have also been shown to have an impact on the production of BEVs and their contents 49–52. Other BEVs may result from bacterial cell lysis due to bacteriophages, and thus represent a pseudo-random assemblage of fragments from different subcellular origins 3,53. To differentiate between these different origins of BEVs, we assessed whether there is an enrichment in non-cytoplasmic proteins in the BEV fraction. Overall, we identified 1,121 proteins that were significantly enriched in BEVs compared to the cellular fraction across the dataset (log2 fold change >1, adjusted p-value < 0.1; Table S3). Prediction of sub-cellular origins revealed that half of the BEV-enriched proteins were non-cytoplasmic, comprising mostly outer membrane and extracellular proteins, compared to ca. 25% of the enriched proteins in the cellular fraction (Fig. 4). Although we cannot specifically identify their production process in our dataset, our results suggest that the packaging of marine BEVs is strongly biased towards proteins of non-cytoplasmic origin.

The enrichment analyses revealed that proteins associated with the cyanobacterial order Synechococcales (families Prochlorococcaceae and Synechococcaceae) made up the largest number of enriched proteins in the BEVs and cellular fractions, proportionally accounting for 17% and 22% of proteins, respectively (Fig. 4). The second largest taxonomic group was the order Pelagibacterales (the SAR11 clade of Alphaproteobacteria), which accounted for 9% of BEV-enriched proteins while comprising 18% of enriched proteins in the cellular fraction. In contrast, enriched proteins associated with other bacterial orders, such as Flavobacteriales (mostly the family Flavobacteriaceae), Alteromonadales (mostly the families Alteromonadaceae and Pseudoalteromonadaceae), and Cellvibrionales (mostly the families Halieaceae and Cellvibrionaceae), accounted for more than twice the relative amount of BEV-enriched proteins compared to the cellular fraction. A previous comparison of isolates from the major classes of marine bacteria suggested that there may be a relationship between growth and BEVs production rates 35. Based on the assumption that the number of enriched proteins reflects the abundance of BEVs to some extent, our results support the previously raised hypothesis that fast-growing bacteria (e.g. Flavobacteria and Alteromonas) contribute more to the BEVs population 35.

It has been postulated that the production of BEVs is influenced by environmental factors that affect their potential ecological impact 16,35. Therefore, to account for the differences in microbial communities and the biogeochemical conditions, we further examined each oceanic province separately. To infer the potential functions of BEVs in the interaction with the extracellular environment, we examined 2,700 outer membrane and extracellular proteins identified in our dataset for enrichment in BEVs. We found a total of 608 of these proteins (Table S4), which were associated with 51 different bacterial lineages (Fig. S5), that were significantly enriched in BEVs compared to bacterial cells. The BEV-enriched proteins were found to be associated with a variety of functional groups, including solute-binding proteins, porins and various ribosomal proteins, as well as numerous proteins whose function is unknown. Different proteins were found enriched in BEVs in different oceanic provinces, suggesting that BEVs may play a role in multiple ecophysiological processes, the main ones of which are discussed below.

sec.title: Marine BEVs as vectors for iron scavenging
sec.p: Iron is a micronutrient that occurs at low concentrations in surface seawater but is vital for life 54. Iron limitation can lead to enhanced BEVs production in non-marine bacteria 55. Preferential packaging of iron-related transporters into BEVs has been proposed to facilitate iron accumulation 52,56,57, and subsequent uptake of such BEVs by bacterial cells has previously been demonstrated in a culture of a pathogenic Gammaproteobacteria 58. To scavenge for iron in the environment, some marine bacteria release siderophores that strongly bind iron, and are subsequently acquired by bacterial cells through specialised TonB-dependent transport systems 59–61. The largest group of proteins that were significantly enriched in marine BEVs consisted of proteins related to the TonB-dependent transport system (Fig. 5), which accounted for 34-47% of all BEV-enriched outer membrane proteins in each region, compared to 22-27% of outer membrane proteins enriched in the cellular fraction (Table S3). The majority of these proteins were TonB-dependent receptors, which are outer membrane proteins that perform high-affinity binding and energy-dependent transport of specific substrates across the membrane 62. Although the exact substrate for most of these receptors is unknown, we were able to identify 7 siderophore-specific TonB-dependent receptors that were enriched in the BEVs across the transect. To actively transport the siderophore across the outer membrane, the TonB-dependent receptor requires proton motive force from the inner membrane 62. While a proton motive force is likely lacking in BEVs, it has recently been demonstrated in a non-marine bacterial isolate that TonB-dependent receptors are capable of binding the siderophores even in the absence of such an energy source 58. Therefore, it is possible that iron or iron-rich proteins are trapped on the BEVs even if they are not internalized.

While production of siderophores in marine bacterial communities is mostly restricted to the class Gammaproteobacteria, the capacity to acquire them from the environment (i.e., synthesizing specific TonB-dependent receptors) is a taxonomically widespread functional trait 22. Nonetheless, the vast majority of the BEV-enriched TonB-dependent receptors we observed was also assigned to members of the class Gammaproteobacteria (orders Alteromonadales and Cellvibrionales, as well as other unclassified lineages), which represented 20-28% of all BEV-enriched outer membrane proteins, compared to 12-16% of outer membrane proteins enriched in the cellular fraction. Enrichment of TonB-dependent receptors on BEVs has been previously observed in cultures of marine Gammaproteobacteria 31,63, among which are also several isolates of the order Alteromonadales 32. Members of Alteromonadales are copiotrophs that thrive under high availability of organic matter 64 and are considered to be major siderophore producers and key mediators of iron acquisition in marine bacterial communities 65,66. We propose that during episodes of high metabolic activity (e.g., associated with increased primary production), Alteromonadales not only release siderophores that bind dissolved iron, but also produce BEVs that ’concentrate’ them in the environment.

Along with nitrogen, iron was the limiting nutrient of surface water primary production across most of the oceanic transect 38. In the transition zone, where there was an elevated cyanobacterial activity without iron limitation, we did not identify any iron-selective porins among the BEV-enriched cyanobacterial proteins, compared to 6 enriched porins in the cellular fraction (Table S4). In contrast, in the westernmost region, where a cyanobacterial activity was observed and iron was identified as one of the limiting nutrients, 14 of the 37 BEV-enriched proteins associated with cyanobacteria (mostly Prochlorococcaceae) were putative iron-selective porins (Fig. 5). We propose that these iron-specific porins form channels that allow passive diffusion of inorganic iron into the BEVs, as they would do in intact cells 67. The inorganic iron could then be bound by periplasmic iron-binding proteins 68, trapping it inside the BEVs.

In ocean regions with limited iron availability, BEVs with the characteristics described above could be considered as nanoscale "hotspots" of bioavailable iron that could potentially be available to marine bacteria in a relatively concentrated form. The producers of these BEVs could be either pelagic (i.e., free-living)34,35, particle-associated 32,63, or associated with phytoplankton cells 30. The BEVs produced by particle- or phytoplankton-associated bacteria are (to some extent) likely to be taken up by the same type of cell, since particle-associated bacteria may live in “microcolonies” 69,70. By contrast, the cells found in the vicinity of a pelagic bacterium are likely to be distinct from the bacterium itself 71. Although we still lack a thorough understanding of iron-related interactions among pelagic marine bacteria 72, we propose two possible mechanisms for the role of BEVs in iron acquisition by marine bacterial communities. One possible scenario is that, similar to siderophores that can be taken up by different taxa 22, and these iron-accumulating marine BEVs could be considered to some extent as ’public goods’ that facilitate the iron needs of the entire bacterial community. However, it has also been shown that in some cases the uptake of BEVs can be selective towards closely related bacterial lineages 56. Although the direct recognition mechanism between bacterial cells and BEVs 73, and the indirect effect of characteristics such as lipid composition and surface charge on BEV uptake remain poorly understood, the available evidence suggests that biases may exist within cell-vesicle interactions. Therefore, the release of iron-accumulating BEVs could also be a means of competing for iron in the marine environment, potentially favouring only closely related phylogenetic populations.

sec.title: Marine BEVs as mediators of extracellular carbohydrate turnover
sec.p: Some "selfish" marine bacteria have developed a strategy to prevent the loss of BEVs through dispersion by producing them in chains that remain partially attached to the cell 30,31. Such chains were first observed in an isolate of Formosa spp. (class Flavobacteriia), and also in an isolate of marine Pseudoalteromonas (class Gammaproteobacteria), where they were proposed to play a role in carbohydrate utilisation based on the transporters and hydrolytic enzyme content of the BEVs. Flavobacteria are predominantly active during elevated availability of organic matter (e.g., during phytoplankton blooms), efficiently utilising various carbohydrates using their unique SusC/D transport system 74,75. Such BEV chains are fragile and were likely detached and disrupted by our filtration steps 30, ending up in the bulk BEVs fraction. In our dataset, we identified 57 different integral SusC-like TonB-dependent transporters that were enriched in the BEVs and 79 SusC-like proteins enriched in the cellular fraction, with an absolute log2 fold change of around 4 (Fig. 5). In contrast, the 25 different extracellular glycan-binding SusD-like proteins, which sit on top of the SusC and bind the substrate 76, comprised more than twice the number of proteins in the BEV fraction than in the cellular fraction, with an absolute log2 fold change of 4-5 compared to 2-4. Taken together with other BEV-enriched flavobacterial proteins (Table S3), our observations are highly consistent with the previously conducted culture-based study of Formosa spp. 30, confirming that flavobacterial BEVs with similar protein content also occur in the natural marine environment.

The SusC/D transport system requires energy from the inner membrane in order to transport substrate across the outer membrane 76. In Formosa spp., based on protein characterization, it has been suggested that the BEV-chains contain to some extent also an inner membrane (indications for which we also observed here, such as the inner membrane SecDF protein and the ExbB proton pump; Table S3), and so it is conceivable that BEV chains may have some ability to take up carbohydrate molecules, which are then transported into the cell 30. However, the stronger enrichment of SusD-like lipoproteins in the BEV fraction compared with SusC suggests a similar mechanism to that proposed above for TonB-dependent receptors, in which such flavobacterial BEVs are more likely to only be able to bind carbohydrate molecules. The trapping of carbohydrate molecules on the cell membrane has been shown to facilitate their efficient digestion by hydrolytic enzymes 26. Recent observations have shown that gut bacteria can actively alter the enzyme content of BEVs to optimise carbohydrate utilisation 77, an analogous process may occur also in marine bacteria. While we lack such a mechanistic understanding for marine BEVs, the presence of hydrolytic enzymes associated with BEVs and their activity has been observed in several isolates of heterotrophic marine bacteria 31,32,78,79. We were also able to identify a single carbohydrate active enzyme (CAZyme - glycoside hydrolase family 16), taxonomically assigned to Flavobacteriales that was enriched in BEVs in the westernmost region (Table S4). We also identified an additional glycoside hydrolase taxonomically affiliated with the Alteromonadales and significantly enriched in BEVs across the entire transect. Conceptually, the association of enzymes with marine BEVs is advantageous because it allows them to be delivered to the substrate in a more protected manner compared to direct excretion, and may also allow for more efficient degradation due to the higher concentration of enzymes that ultimately reach the target molecule 1. While it is widely accepted that marine bacteria release hydrolytic enzymes into the extracellular milieu to facilitate carbohydrate degradation 80, the evidence above suggests that part of this secretion occurs via marine BEVs.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Here we have characterised the abundance and diversity of marine BEVs on an extensive oceanic scale, integrating their ecological and biogeochemical contexts. We found that marine BEVs are ubiquitous in seawater and possess a substantial degree of protein diversity. A relationship was identified between the enrichment of certain cargoes of BEVs and the ecological conditions experienced by the local bacterial community, thus confirming their potential role in the scavenging of extracellular nutrients and energy. The next stage of the research requires methodological investigation into the mechanisms underlying BEV uptake, as this is a major gap in our understanding of the relationship between BEVs and bacterial cells. It also requires quantitative experiments on the contribution of BEVs to extracellular enzymatic activity and iron accumulation in marine bacterial communities. We argue that future research on extracellular processes in marine bacterial communities should consider the possibility that characterisations of bulk seawater may conflate activity mediated by ’truly’ dissolved molecules (e.g. siderophores and enzymes) with activity associated with BEVs, the products of which may not be equally available to all cells.

sec.title: Sample collection
sec.p: The oceanographic sampling was conducted onboard RV Sonne (cruise SO289 representing section GP21 of the GEOTRACES program) from 18 February to 8 April 2022 (Fig. 1). Water samples with a total volume of 60 L were taken from a depth of ca. 6 m at each sampling station using the onboard water pump. To remove particulate matter and eukaryotic cells, water samples were pre-filtered at low pressure using a 3 μm pore-size membrane filter (Merck Millipore, MA, USA). From the pre-filtered water sample, 1 mL was preserved with 4% glutaraldehyde (final concentration) and stored at -80°C until flow cytometric analysis. The pre-filtered seawater sample was then filtered through a 142 mm diameter polycarbonate filter with a pore-size of 0.22 μm (Merck Millipore, MA, USA), which was then stored at -80°C and later used for molecular analyses of the bacterial communities. The filtrate (< 0.22 μm) was concentrated ca. 60 times using a Vivaflow tangential flow filtration system (Sartorius, Germany) with a 100 kDa cut-off to 1 L and stored at -20°C until further BEVs purification in the laboratory.

sec.title: Phytoplankton pigments analysis
sec.p: Seawater samples (2-4 L) for diagnostic phytoplankton pigments were filtered onto MF300 glass fibre filters (ThermoFisher Scientific, MA, USA) and stored at -80°C until analysis. Pigment extraction and analysis followed the procedure described by 19. Briefly, upon return to a land-based laboratory, pigments were extracted in 90% acetone by homogenization of the filters using glass beads in a cell mill, centrifuged (10 minutes, 5200 rpm, 4 °C). The supernatant was filtered through 0.2 μm PTFE filters (VWR, PA, USA) and subsequently analysed by reverse-phase high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) Dionex UltiMate 3000 LC system (ThermoFisher Scientific, MA, USA)81. Diagnostic pigments were converted to estimate contributions of different phytoplankton types using CHEMTAX 82, with initial pigment ratios according to 83. Total chlorophyll-a derived from HPLC include both chlorophyll-a and divinyl chlorophyll-a, and is referred to as chlorophyll-a throughout this study.

sec.title: Bacterial cell counts
sec.p: Bacterial cells were stained with 1×SYBR Green I (Thermo Fisher Scientific, MA, USA) for 15 min and then quantified using a flow cytometer Accuri™ C6 (BD Biosciences, NJ, USA). Counts were processed using R package ’flowWorkspace’ v4.18.0 84 and stained cells were quantified using the ‘gate_flowclust_2d’ function in R package ‘openCyto’ 85.

sec.title: BEVs isolation and purification
sec.p: A sub-sample of 100 mL of concentrated seawater was further concentrated about 30 times to a final volume of 3 mL using Vivaspin centrifugal filter units (Sartorius, Germany) with a 100 kDa cut-off. The entire concentrate was then loaded onto an iodixanol density gradient following a published protocol 86, and centrifuged at 100,000xg at 4°C for 6 hours. In the 15-30% and 35-40% fractions, the iodixanol solution was exchanged twice with 1×PBS using Vivaspin centrifugal filter units with a 100 kDa cut-off at 2000×g, and resuspended in 1 mL 1 ×PBS. From each purified fraction, 800 μL was used for molecular analyses and 200 μL for quantification of BEVs.

sec.title: Nanoparticle tracking analysis
sec.p: The abundance of BEVs was measured by nanoparticle tracking analysis (NTA) using a NanoSight NS300 instrument (Malvern Panalytycal, UK) equipped with a 488 nm laser. Each sample was injected using a syringe pump with a flow speed of 100 μL min-1, and five videos of 60 sec were recorded. Videos were analysed using NanoSight NTA software v3.2. All particles in the size up to 300 nm in both the 15-30% and 35-40% fractions were included in the final abundance estimates. The flow cell was thoroughly flushed with Milli-Q water (Merck Millipore) between samples, and visually examined to exclude carry over. The performance of the instrument was routinely checked by measuring the concentration and size distribution of standardized 100 nm silica beads.

sec.title: Metagenomics workflow
sec.p: One third of the polycarbonate filters with a pore size of 0.22 μm were used for the extraction of genomic DNA using the DNeasy PowerWater Kit (QIAGEN N.V., Germany) according to the manufacturer’s recommendations. The extracted DNA was subject to enzymatic shearing and then shotgun sequencing, performed on two lanes of the NovaSeq S4 platform (Illumina, Inc., CA, USA) at the Vienna Biocenter Core Facilities (https://www.viennabiocenter.org/vbcf/_next-generation-sequencing/).

The sequences from all samples were subject to the snakemake 87 metagenomic workflow in Anvi’o v8 88, with recommended parameters. Briefly, the raw FASTQ files were subject to quality control by ’illumina-utils’ v2.13 89 and taxonomic classification using KrakenUniq v1.0.4 90 and analysed using R package ’pavian’ v1.2.1 91. Then the reads were assembled using MEGAHIT v1.2.9 92 and the gene calling was performed using Prodigal v2.6.3 93. To construct the database for downstream metaproteomic analysis, protein-coding genes were clustered at 99% similarity using CD-HIT v4.6.881 94.

Taxonomic affiliation of the gene calls was estimated using Kaiju v1.9.2 95 against the NCBI RefSeq database (date: 2024-08-14), followed by classification of sequences with unknown taxonomic affiliation against the NCBI nr database (date: 2024-08-25). Functional annotation of the genes was carried out against InterPro v98 96, NCBIfam v17.0 97, Pfam v37 98 databases using InterProScan v5.66 99. The unidentified protein sequences with no hits, were assigned taxonomy and function using BLASTp 100 best-hit approach, against NCBI RefSeq database (date: 2025-01-27). Protein sub-cellular localization was estimated using a combination of PSORTb v3.0.6 101 and Phobius v1.01 102.

sec.title: Proteomics workflow
sec.p: We used the remaining two thirds of the polycarbonate filters with a pore size of 0.22 μm for extraction of cellular proteins. Protein extraction from the filter was performed as described in detail by 103. Briefly, the filters were ground into small pieces with a sterile metal spatula after submerging the tubes with the filters into liquid nitrogen. Filter pieces were resuspended in lysis buffer (100mM Tris-HCl pH 7.4, 1% SDS, 150mM NaCl, 1mM DTT, 10mM EDTA) and cells were lysed with five freeze-and-thaw cycles. After centrifugation (20,000x g at 4°C for 25 min) the supernatant was transferred into a tube and proteins were co-precipitated with 0.015% deoxycholate and 7% trichloroacetic acid (TCA) on ice for 1h and washed twice with ice-cold acetone. Dried protein pellets were resuspended in 50 mM TEAB buffer (Millipore Sigma, Burlington, MA, USA) and cysteines were reduced and alkylated with 10 mM DTT and 55 mM iodoacetamide (IAA), respectively. To extract proteins associated with the BEVs, we added the sample reducing agent NuPAGE (Invitrogen, Waltham, MA, USA) to 600 μL of purified BEVs at 1X final concentration.

All samples were re-precipitated using 9 times the sample volume of 96% EtOH at -20°C overnight. Pellets were resuspended in 50 mM TEAB, followed by overnight in-solution trypsin (Roche, Basel, Switzerland) digestion (1:100, w/w) at 37°C. TFA was added to the samples at 1% final concentration to terminate trypsin digestion. Samples were desalted using Pierce C18 Tips (ThermoFisher Scientific, MA, USA) according to the manufacturer’s protocol. Prior the LC-MS analysis, digested peptides were dissolved in 0.1% formic acid and 2% acetonitrile.

Purified tryptic peptides were dissolved in 0.1% formic acid (FA) and measured using a nano-reversed-phase high-performance liquid chromatography (RP-HPLC) system Dionex Ultimate 3000 (ThermoFisher Scientific, MA, USA), coupled with a benchtop Quadrupole Orbitrap mass spectrometer Q-Exactive Plus (ThermoFisher Scientific, MA, USA). Peptides were separated on a PepMap RSLC C18 column (ThermoFisher Scientific, MA, USA) at 55°C with a flow rate of 300 nL/min. The two-hour segmented LC gradient ranged from 5% to 80% buffer B (79.9% acetonitrile, 0.1% FA). Mass spectra were acquired in positive ion mode using a top-15 data-dependent acquisition method. Full MS scans were performed at a resolution of 70,000 (m/z 200), followed by MS/MS scans at a resolution of 17,500. High-energy collisional dissociation (HCD) fragmentation was applied with a normalized collision energy (NCE) of 30%. Dynamic exclusion was set to 60 seconds.

The MS raw files of proteins extracted from the bacterial cells and the BEVs were searched using SEQUEST-HT against the bacterial protein coding genes from the co-assembled metagenome. Search parameters were as follows: enzyme - trypsin, fragment mass tolerance - 0.8 Da, max. missed cleavages - 2, fixed modifications - carbamidomethyl (Cys), optional modifications - oxidation (Met). Percolator parameters were as follows: max. delta Cn: 0.6, max. rank: 0, validation based on q-value, false discovery rate (calculated by automatic decoy searches) 0.05. Only proteins with more than two peptides and at least one unique peptide were included in the statistical analyses.

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: Statistical analyses were done in R v4.4.2 (R Core Team 2022) using RStudio v2024.09.1 (RStudio Team 2019). Protein enrichment analysis was performed using the R package ’DEqMS’ v1.22.0 104 on a log2-transformed and median-centred protein abundance matrix. In the enrichment test, only those proteins were included that were observed in at least two samples in each fraction. All figures were generated using the R package ’ggplot2’ v3.5.1 105.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We thank the captain, the crew and the scientific team of the RV SONNE SO289 GEOTRACES research expedition (‘S Pacific GEOTRACES’, 03G0289NA, funded by the Bundesministerium für Bildung und Forschung (BMBF)). We thank A. Mutzberg, D. Jasinski, F. Evers, T. Schott, K. Nachtigall and T. Klüver for technical support. We thank Z. Steiner for his support during the expedition. M. Aubert for assistance with laboratory sample processing. EF acknowledges funding by the Austrian Science Fund (FWF) M2797-B. This work was also supported by the Austrian Science Fund (FWF) project I4978-B to GJH and by the Slovenian Research Agency (ARIS) project J7-2599 to TT.

sec.title: Data availability
sec.p: The metagenomic raw sequences have been deposited in the European Nucleotide Archive (ENA) at EMBL-EBI under Project accession number PRJEB88044. The mass spectrometry proteomics data have been deposited to the ProteomeXchange Consortium 106 via the PRIDE 107 partner repository with the dataset identifier PXD062682.

Scripts for data processing and statistical analyses, as well as raw flow cytometry and NTA files, can be accessed via Zenodo (https://www.zenodo.org/) under doi: 10.5281/zenodo.15772523 and 10.5281/zenodo.15772578, respectively.

fn.p: EF performed fieldwork, the bioinformatic and statistical analyses, and wrote the manuscript. EF and GJH designed the project. EF, NO, TT performed the protein extraction and LAS carried out the LC-MS measurements. HL, ZY and TJB performed the phytoplankton pigment sampling and analyses. EPA was the chief scientist on board and coordinated the sampling. DS and SJB contributed to data interpretation. All authors contributed to the manuscript and approved its submitted version.

caption.title: Diverse biogeochemical regimes encountered across the South Pacific Ocean.
caption.p: (A) Spatial grouping of the sampling stations according to the four oceanic provinces: ‘UP’ - Chilean coastal upwelling zone; ‘TRAN’ - transition zone between the upwelling and the subtropical gyre; ‘GYRE’ - South Pacific subtropical gyre; ‘WEST’ - westernmost region. Chl. a concentration is overlaid on the cruise transect, with the grey scale background representing the bathymetry.(B) The composition of the surface water phytoplankton at each station, estimated on the basis of diagnostic pigments.

caption.title: Bacterial community composition based on taxonomic classification of metagenomic sequences.
caption.p: ‘Other classes < 0.5%’ – refers to taxonomic classes that comprised less than 0.5% of the sequences; ‘unclassified’ – refers to bacterial sequences with unknown classification on a class level. All samples contained 2-5×108 classified sequences.

caption.title: Bacterial cell and EVs abundances across different provinces.
caption.p: The abundances were determined by flow cytometry and nanoparticle tracking analysis (NTA), respectively. The N represents the number of stations in each province.

caption.title: Proportions of significantly enriched proteins between BEV and cellular fractions.
caption.p: Proportion of enriched proteins in each fraction according to their predicted sub-cellular origins (A) and taxonomic affiliation (B). The total number of enriched proteins in the BEVs and the cellular fractions was 1121 and 2075, respectively. Taxonomic affiliations of enriched proteins in the cellular and BEVs fractions according to different oceanic provinces. The taxonomic class of each order is given in parentheses: ‘A’ – Alphaproteobacterial, ‘C’ – Cytophagia, ‘CY’ – Cyanophyceae, ‘F’ – Flavobacteriia, ‘G’ – Gammaproteobacteria.

caption.title: Enrichment of selected groups of proteins in marine BEVs.
caption.p: The upper panel shows the enrichment in BEVs and the lower panel shows the enrichment in the cellular fraction. ‘Porins’ – includes the cyanobacterial iron-specific porins and the putative carbohydrate-selective porin OprB.’SusC/D’ - includes both the SusC- and SusD-like proteins of the flavobacterial carbohydrate transport system. ‘TBDR’ – includes various TonB-dependent receptors. The total number of enriched proteins is indicated by the size of each circle and the number next to it.
